desc.size: Medium-sized to large tree, 12 - 24 m tall, trunk diameter 25 - 40 cm. Crown rounded, with many spreading, slender branches.

part.partText: gray or light brown, thin, smooth, becoming warty, rough, and scaly with age.
slender, gray to reddish brown, slightly zigzag, smooth or hairy, shiny. Leaf scars crescent-shaped with 1 - 3 bundle scars.
light brown or gray, 3 - 6 mm long, slender, egg-shaped, pointed, finely hairy.

alternate, with short, hairy leafstalks; shiny green above, paler with hairy veins beneath, 5 - 14 cm long, half as wide, broadly lance-shaped; asymmetrical base rounded or tapering, tip long-pointed, margins coarsely toothed except near base, thin, smooth or somewhat rough on one or both surfaces; veins in a lacelike pattern. Leaves turning light yellow in autumn.
either male or female, borne on the same tree (monoecious); in drooping clusters or solitary; greenish yellow, inconspicuous, without petals.
fleshy, single-seeded (drupe); borne on slender, drooping stalks; dark purple, 7 - 13 cm long, nearly round, smooth, becoming puckered and prune-like; pit wrinkled; persistent in winter.

similarSpecies.comments: Of the two Celtis species found in the Chicago Region, this one is much more common. It can be distinguished from Celtis tenuifolia by its larger size, larger, long-tipped, coarsely toothed leaves (usually), and larger, dark purple fruits on long (1 - 2 cm) stalks. Also, the presence of hackberry nipple-gall and witches’ broom is common on C. occidentalis. Note: Leaves may resemble those of Ulmus, but Celtis species have three main veins arising from the base of each blade.

speciesPage.flowering: Mid-April to early May, after the leaves are partly grown.
speciesPage.habitatEcology: Frequent in moist woods, often in and along floodplains of streams.

notes.comments: The wood of Celtis occidentalis is used for furniture, fence posts, boxes, and crates. It is easily transplanted and valued as a lawn and park tree. A type of “witches’ broom,” caused by mites and fungi, is often seen on twigs throughout the crown, and nipple-galls are common on the leaves.

etymology.comments: Celtis is the Greek word for the hackberry tree (hackberry is actually a corruption of the Scottish name Hagberry, a species of cherry tree). Occidentalis means “of or from the West.”
